columns.text: In this case, an insurance firm offers insurance for children that requires annual payments from the first to the sixth year, and the child will earn $300,000 after 65 years. We'll see if the policy given is worth buying if the interest rate is 10% for the first six years and 7% for the remaining years.

In our calculation, we will refer to the projected cash flows of the insurance premiums and the following detail from the problem:

| Partculars                                |     |
|-------------------------------------------|-----|
| Interest rate for the first six years     | 10% |
| Intrest rate for the seventh year onwards | 7%  |
| Policy period                             | 65  |

To determine if the policy is worth buying, we will calculate the policy's future value based on the relevant interest rates and compare the result with the given payout of $300,000 from the offered insurance policy after 65 years.
We'll divide our computation into two parts as the insurance policy has two different interest rates for various periods (10% for the first six years and 7% onwards after that).

Let's begin by calculating the net future value of the cash flows in six years, referring to the projected cash flows, using the provided interest rate of 10%, and discounting each cash flow based on their respective years backward.

The future value of a series of cash flows is the value of an amount at a future date. It is determined by considering the interest rate, the present amounts, and the compounding period. As a result, the formula for calculating the future value is:

$$ \begin{aligned}
FV &={CF}\times{\left(1 + r\right)^{t}}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$FV$, which means the future value\
$CF$, which refers to the cash flow\
$t$, which represent the period\
$r$, which indicate the discount rate

As a result of our computation, the future value of the cash flows at various periods are as follows:

| Year | Future value ($) |
|------|------------------|
| 1    |   1,127.36       |
| 2    |   1,024.87       |
| 3    |   1,064.80       |
| 4    |      968.00      |
| 5    |      990.00      |
| 6    |      900.00      |

Let's now determine the policy's future value in the sixth year.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{FV of Sixth Year}&=\$ 1,127.36+\$1,024.87 +\$1,064.80+\$968+ 990+900
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\bf\$6,075.03}
\end{aligned}$$

As can be seen in our calculation, the future value of the series of cash flows is $6,075.03.

Let's calculate the policy's future value for the remainder of its term now that we have the future value at a 10% rate. Because there will be no payment after six years, we will use the sixth year's future value as the present value. Also, as stated in the problem, the interest rate from the seventh year onwards is 7%; therefore, we will use that rate in our calculation.

Comparing the payout from the policy after 65 years of $300,000 and the future value of the cash flows of $328,996.36, we can clearly understand the future value of the cash flows are worth more than the payout from the policy.

**As a result, the policy is not worth buying.**
